column5: In case people are wondering, I talked to my lodge owner last week at the All Canada Show and he said the water (on Wabigoon and related lakes) would be up again this year. The snow at the time near Dryden was 4 1/2 feet deep. T-125 days before we go...but who's counting!!

[font color=green size=3][b]The water level on Wabaskang came up 10"-12" between Labor Day and ice up last fall, which isn't the norm. With the snow in the bush this winter I'm thinking the water level will be higher this spring, but it doesn't usually rise until after ice out. So the earlier ice out comes the more time for the water to rise.

Rebelrn, I am going to the cottage on Dinorwic with the snowmobile in three weeks or so. They say the ice is only on 1 to 1-1/2 feet thick because of all the snow. I plan to poke a few holes in the ice but promise to stay on my side of the channel. Hope to hook up with a friend and snowmobile to a lake trout lake just to the south. It is just like waiting for Christmas isn't it.

Skylane. Better. Christmas is only 1 day. Canada is like 7 Christmas'in a row (unless the weather is like last year). Where you from and where on Dinorwic do you have a cabin? We're from Green Bay area.

Your right about last year. One of the locals told me last summer that they had 11 straight months of winter. I am a farmer from central Illinois. The cottage is on the East shore of the lake, the first place South of Brown Bay (3/4 mile).
